Yes, in my experience, tearDown is always called.  From the JUnit code:

cl=
ass TestCase {
	...
	public void runBare() throws Throwable {
		setUp();
		=
try {
			runTest();
		}
		finally {
			tearDown();
		}
	}

essage-----
From: Laurent Duperval [mailto:lduperval@...]
Sent:=
 Monday, October 22, 2001 2:10 PM
To: JUnit Mailing list
Subject: [junit] I=
f a test fails (on an error), is tearDown called
anyway?


Hi,

In the proc=
ess of debugging my transaction problem reported last Friday, I
decided to =
recode the offending tests so they are no longer transactional.
I've found =
that if the test is run alone, it passes, but if it is run within
a slew of=
 test suites (AllTests), it fails. If we take the test suite for
the offend=
ing class and put it first in AllTests, it passes.

In our transactional te=
sts, the tearDown method ends the transaction. If a
test fails because of a=
n error, is tearDown called nevertheless? Has anyone
seen weird side effect=
s where a test run standAlone passes but fails when
run with others?

No, a=
t this point, I can't say that it's due to data cleanup. All our tests
recr=
eate data when they are run. Furthermore, most of our data uses database
se=
quence numbers as the primary key so every test run uses a new set of
data.=
 Even if previous data was still in the DB, it can't be mapped to the
new d=
ata.
